abstract.p: This document defines the JSON schema for testing Extendable Output Function implementations with the ACVP specification.

abstract.title: Abstract
abstract.p: This document defines the JSON schema for testing Extendable Output Function implementations with the ACVP specification.

foreword.title: Foreword
foreword.p: The Information Technology Laboratory (ITL) at the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) promotes the U.S. economy and public welfare by providing technical leadership for the Nation’s measurement and standards infrastructure. ITL develops tests, test methods, reference data, proof of concept implementations, and technical analyses to advance the development and productive use of information technology. ITL’s responsibilities include the development of management, administrative, technical, and physical standards and guidelines for the cost-effective security and privacy of other than national security-related information in federal information systems. The Special Publication 800-series reports on ITL’s research, guidelines, and outreach efforts in information system security, and its collaborative activities with industry, government, and academic organizations.

clause.title: Audience
clause.p: This document is intended for the users and developers of ACVP.

clause.title: Conventions
clause.p: The key words “MUST”, “MUST NOT”, “REQUIRED”, “SHALL”, “SHALL NOT”, “SHOULD”, “SHOULD NOT”, “RECOMMENDED”, “NOT RECOMMENDED”, “MAY”, and “OPTIONAL” in this document are to be interpreted as described in BCP 14 of and when, and only when, they appear in all capitals, as shown here.

acknowledgements.title: Acknowledgements
acknowledgements.p: This document is produced by the Security Testing, Validation and Measurement group under the Automated Cryptographic Validation Testing (ACVT) program.

executivesummary.title: Executive Summary
executivesummary.p: The Automated Crypto Validation Protocol (ACVP) defines a mechanism to automatically verify the cryptographic implementation of a software or hardware crypto module. The ACVP specification defines how a crypto module communicates with an ACVP server, including crypto capabilities negotiation, session management, authentication, vector processing and more. The ACVP specification does not define algorithm specific JSON constructs for performing the crypto validation. A series of ACVP sub-specifications define the constructs for testing individual crypto algorithms. Each sub-specification addresses a specific class of crypto algorithms. This sub-specification defines the JSON constructs for testing Extendable Output Function implementations using ACVP.

clause.title: Introduction
clause.p: The Automated Crypto Validation Protocol (ACVP) defines a mechanism to automatically verify the cryptographic implementation of a software or hardware crypto module. The ACVP specification defines how a crypto module communicates with an ACVP server, including crypto capabilities negotiation, session management, authentication, vector processing and more. The ACVP specification does not define algorithm specific JSON constructs for performing the crypto validation. A series of ACVP sub-specifications define the constructs for testing individual crypto algorithms. Each sub-specification addresses a specific class of crypto algorithms. This sub-specification defines the JSON constructs for testing Extendable Output Function implementations using ACVP.

clause.title: Supported Algorithms
clause.p: The following XOFs may be advertised by this ACVP compliant crypto module:
Other XOFs may be advertised by the ACVP elsewhere.

clause.title: Test Types and Test Coverage
clause.p: This section describes the design of the tests used to validate Extendable Output Function implementations.

clause.title: Test Types
clause.p: This section describes the design of the tests used to validate implementations of XOFs. There are three types of tests for these algorithms: Algorithm Functional Tests (AFT), Monte Carlo Tests (MCT) and MAC Verification Tests (MVT). Each has a specific value to be used in the testType field. The testType field definitions are:

li.p: “AFT” — Algorithm Functional Tests. These tests can be processed by the client using a normal ‘encrypt’ or ‘decrypt’ operation. AFTs cause the implementation under test to exercise normal operations on a single block, multiple blocks, or (where applicable) partial blocks. In some cases random data is used, in others, static, predetermined tests are provided.

“MCT” — Monte Carlo Tests. These tests exercise the implementation under test under strenuous circumstances. The implementation under test must process the test vectors according to the correct algorithm and mode in this document. MCTs can help detect potential memory leaks over time, and problems in allocation of resources, addressing variables, error handling and generally improper behavior in response to random inputs. Each MCT processes 100 pseudorandom tests. Not every algorithm and mode combination has an MCT. See for implementation details.

clause.title: cSHAKE Monte Carlo Test
ParallelHash Monte Carlo Test
TupleHash Monte Carlo Test
BitsToString Function
Test Coverage
clause.p: The tests described in this document have the intention of ensuring an implementation is conformant to .

clause.title: XOF Requirements Covered
clause.p: In TBD.

clause.title: XOF Requirements Not Covered
clause.p: Some requirements in the outlined specification are not easily tested. Often they are not ideal for black-box testing such as the ACVP. In TBD.

clause.title: Capabilities Registration
clause.p: ACVP requires crypto modules to register their capabilities. This allows the crypto module to advertise support for specific algorithms, notifying the ACVP server which algorithms need test vectors generated for the validation process. This section describes the constructs for advertising support of XOF algorithms to the ACVP server.

The algorithm capabilities MUST be advertised as JSON objects within the ‘algorithms’ value of the ACVP registration message. The ‘algorithms’ value is an array, where each array element is an individual JSON object defined in this section. The ‘algorithms’ value is part of the ‘capability_exchange’ element of the ACVP JSON registration message. See the ACVP specification for more details on the registration message.

clause.title: Prerequisites
clause.p: Each algorithm implementation MAY rely on other cryptographic primitives. For example, RSA Signature algorithms depend on an underlying hash function. Each of these underlying algorithm primitives must be validated, either separately or as part of the same submission. ACVP provides a mechanism for specifying the required prerequisites:

Prerequisites, if applicable, MUST be submitted in the registration as the prereqVals JSON property array inside each element of the algorithms array. Each element in the prereqVals array MUST contain the following properties
A “valValue” of “same” SHALL be used to indicate that the prerequisite is being met by a different algorithm in the capability exchange in the same registration.
An example description of prerequisites within a single algorithm capability exchange looks like this

clause.title: XOF Algorithm Capabilities Registration
clause.p: This section describes the constructs for advertising support of XOFs to the ACVP server. ACVP REQUIRES cryptographic modules to register their capabilities in a registration. This allows the cryptographic module to advertise support for specific algorithms, notifying the ACVP server which algorithms need test vectors generated for the validation process.

The XOF capabilities MUST be advertised as JSON objects within the ‘algorithms’ value of the ACVP registration message. The ‘algorithms’ value MUST be an array, where each array element is an individual JSON object defined in this section. The ‘algorithms’ value MUST be part of the ‘capability_exchange’ element of the ACVP JSON registration message.
Each XOF algorithm capability advertised SHALL be a self-contained JSON object.
Each algorithm capability advertised is a self-contained JSON object. The following JSON values are used for XOF algorithm capabilities:

tr.td: The algorithm and mode to be validated.
The algorithm testing revision to use.
Implementation has the ability to act as an XOF or a non-XOF algorithm

An optional feature to the implementation. When true, “hex” customization strings are supported, otherwise they aren’t. ASCII strings SHALL be tested regardless of the value within the hexCustomization property.
blockSize (in bits) to be used with ParallelHash

clause.p: The following grid outlines which properties are REQUIRED, as well as all the possible values a server MAY support for XOF algorithms:

note.p: For cSHAKE, ParallelHash, and TupleHash, the value for the outputLen property must consist either of a single range object or a single literal value. This restriction is made to simplify the implementation of the Monte Carlo Tests for these algorithms (see ).

clause.title: Test Vectors
clause.p: The ACVP server provides test vectors to the ACVP client, which are then processed and returned to the ACVP server for validation. A typical ACVP validation test session would require multiple test vector sets to be downloaded and processed by the ACVP client. Each test vector set represents an individual algorithm defined during the capability exchange. This section describes the JSON schema for a test vector set used with Extendable Output Function algorithms.

The test vector set JSON schema is a multi-level hierarchy that contains meta data for the entire vector set as well as individual test vectors to be processed by the ACVP client. The following table describes the JSON elements at the top level of the hierarchy.

table.name: Top Level Test Vector JSON Elements

tr.td: Algorithm defined in the capability exchange
Mode defined in the capability exchange
Array of test groups containing test data, see

clause.p: An example of this would look like this

clause.title: Test Groups
clause.p: Test vector sets MUST contain one or many test groups, each sharing similar properties. For instance, all test vectors that use the same key size would be grouped together. The testGroups element at the top level of the test vector JSON object SHALL be the array of test groups. The Test Group JSON object MUST contain meta-data that applies to all test cases within the group. The following table describes the JSON elements that MUST appear from the server in the Test Group JSON object:

tr.td: Numeric identifier for the test group, unique across the entire vector set
Test category type. AFT, MCT or MVT as defined in
Whether or not the group uses the arbitrary output (XOF) version of the algorithm
Whether or not the group uses customization strings in hex (true) or ASCII (false)
Array of individual test case JSON objects, which are defined in

clause.title: Test Case JSON Schema
clause.p: Each test group SHALL contain an array of one or more test cases. Each test case is a JSON object that represents a single case to be processed by the ACVP client. The following table describes the JSON elements for each test case.

tr.td: Numeric identifier for the test case, unique across the entire vector set
Length of the message or seed for cSHAKE, KMAC and ParallelHash
Length of each tuple for TupleHash
The function name used in the XOF
The ASCII customization string used (between 0 and 161 ASCII characters in length)
The hex customization string used (between 0 and 322 hex characters in length)
Value of the message or seed. Messages are represented as little-endian hex for all SHA3 variations
Length of the key used in KMAC
The tuple of messages used in TupleHash

clause.title: Test Vector Responses
clause.p: After the ACVP client downloads and processes a vector set, it SHALL send the response vectors back to the ACVP server within the alloted timeframe. The following table describes the JSON object that represents a vector set response.

tr.td: Unique numeric identifier for the vector set
Array of JSON objects that represent each test vector result, which uses the same JSON schema as defined in

clause.p: The testGroup Response section is used to organize the ACVP client response in a similar manner to how it receives vectors. Several algorithms SHALL require the client to send back group level properties in its response. This structure helps accommodate that.

table.name: Vector Set Group Response JSON Object

tr.td: The tests associated to the group specified in tgId

clause.p: Each test case is a JSON object that represents a single test object to be processed by the ACVP client. The following table describes the JSON elements for each test case object.

tr.td: Numeric identifier for the test case, unique across the entire vector set
The IUT’s MAC response to an AFT for KMAC
The IUT’s reponse to an MVT for KMAC
The IUT’s digest response to an AFT
The output length of the digest
Array of JSON objects that represent each iteration of an MCT. Each iteration will contain the md and outLen
array of objects containing the md and outLen

note.p: The tcId MUST be included in every test case object sent between the client and the server.

clause.title: Security Considerations
clause.p: There are no additional security considerations outside of those outlined in the ACVP document.

annex.title: Terminology
annex.p: For the purposes of this document, the following terms and definitions apply.

verbal-definition.p: JSON sent from the server to the client describing the tests the client performs
The initial request from the client to the server describing the capabilities of one or several algorithm, mode and revision combinations
JSON sent from the client to the server in response to the prompt
An individual unit of work within a prompt or response
A collection of test cases that share similar properties within a prompt or response
A collection of test groups under a specific algorithm, mode, and revision
JSON sent from the server to the client that specifies the correctness of the response

bibitem.title: Key words for use in RFCs to Indicate Requirement Levels

abstract.p: In many standards track documents several words are used to signify the requirements in the specification. These words are often capitalized. This document defines these words as they should be interpreted in IETF documents. This document specifies an Internet Best Current Practices for the Internet Community, and requests discussion and suggestions for improvements.

bibitem.title: Ambiguity of Uppercase vs Lowercase in RFC 2119 Key Words

abstract.p: RFC 2119 specifies common key words that may be used in protocol specifications. This document aims to reduce the ambiguity by clarifying that only UPPERCASE usage of the key words have the defined special meanings.
